Award.AwardTitle: Convergence Accelerator Phase I (RAISE): Upskilling for Future Jobs through NLx Talent Demand Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and show potential for deliverables in the near future.

The broader impact/potential benefit of this Convergence Accelerator Phase I project will be the creation of publicly available datasets based on aggregated job vacancy information. Team members will converge across disciplines to include private sector recruitment experts, staff of the public workforce development system, labor economists, data scientists, and software developers. The project will deliver actionable real-time labor market information (LMI) to an increasingly dynamic, open, connected, and individual-centered workforce data ecosystem. The resulting research and derived data products will contribute to the design of career planning tools for job seekers, learners, transitioning service members (veterans), and military spouses, as well as their career counselors in the public workforce system. Employers may utilize the research insights and tools to improve job matching through clearer job descriptions, thus increasing skills-based hiring. Over time, equitable access to worker-centered tools for career planning will enhance the employment resiliency of American workers.

The Convergence Accelerator Phase I project will establish infrastructure and partnerships to increase the quality, quantity, and availability of real-time LMI for the nation. Automation and frequently shifting skill requirements necessitate access to real-time information along every part of the talent pipeline. However, production of the set of resources that complements "traditional" LMI in the public workforce system - real-time information on job vacancies - has been largely confined to the private sector for over a decade. To enable an open and accessible workforce data ecosystem of the future, the team will (1) create open code to collect, validate, clean, and store data; (2) establish governance procedures to make raw data available to researchers; (3) test the technical and statistical feasibility of incorporating external data sets; (4) explore the development of predictive artificial intelligence tools to extract skill and competency phrases from job descriptions; and (5) explore the development of worker-centered resources for the American public. By emphasizing transparency and open-source tools, the project will promote innovation around skill frameworks and methods of harmonizing labor market data sets in a constantly evolving workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the creation of the National Labor Exchange (NLx) Research Hub – the first national, open ecosystem of real-time and historical labor market information to improve connections between jobseekers and employers. Through this exploration, three primary outcomes were achieved.

First, the team designed a prototype technical infrastructure for the NLx Research Hub that will allow authorized researchers to access over 130 million unique job posting records at no cost. Test users from 14 different organizations received data samples and provided critical feedback on data attributes and the proposed architecture. The prototype website NLxResearchHub.org demonstrates future capabilities of the design.

Second, the team developed governance protocols to make raw NLx data available to researchers. The NLx is a public-private labor exchange system created in 2007 by the National Association of State Workforce Agencies and DirectEmployers Association. These entities have a formal partnership governed by long-standing operational agreements. However, these agreements did not cover external researcher access to NLx data. The project included several intensive sessions to define tiers of data sensitivity, the structure of the governing body, language for researcher agreement forms, and other legal documentation. The NLx Data Trust Agreement went into effect in June 2020, permitting the NLx data to power a variety of future research projects. In 2021 the NLx Data Trust will grant data access to every state workforce agency, resulting in an immediate benefit to the public workforce system and the workers it serves.

Third, a variety of data analyses and discovery interviews illuminated the strengths and limitations of the NLx data, potential use cases, and labor market information tools that could be offered to the American public. A data review helped prioritize data cleaning tasks, and demonstrated the feasibility of integrating NLx data with other types of labor market information. The test users and other interviewees recognized job posting data as a unique resource with a rich amount of detail related to skills, educational requirements, and job activities. High-priority use cases include talent supply and demand analysis, connecting jobseekers to workforce services, snapshot publications, skill trend analysis using emerging artificial intelligence methods, and customized job search tools.

The discovery process clarified several key differences between the design of the NLx Research Hub and other sources of job data: quality, cost-efficiency, transparency, timeliness, and trust. The NLx is a trusted partner to over 300,000 employers and the workforce development agencies of all 50 states, DC, Guam, and Puerto Rico. This unique network will help the NLx Research Hub’s data reach a national audience. Several stakeholder interviews indicated that for-profit job boards and data products often keep their sourcing and aggregation methods private; this makes it difficult to validate the data and connect it to other information sources. Moreover, it is inefficient for every locality or state to buy a separate data license. This project finalized a design for the NLx Research Hub that will make job posting data more readily available to inform the future of work.
